keyTakeAways: Nicolas Sarkozy, former President of France, is serving a five-year jail term for criminal conspiracy related to illegal campaign funding from Muammar Gaddafi.
Sarkozy is the first former head of a European Union state to be imprisoned, making the case a landmark in European political history.
He was found guilty of accepting millions of euros in illegal payments during his 2007 election campaign, which he has consistently denied.
He is being held in solitary confinement in La Sante prison, with limited contact with other inmates and scheduled visits three times a week.
Sarkozy’s imprisonment marks the first time a French head of state has been jailed since Philippe Petain after World War II, highlighting the gravity of the legal and political implications.
His lawyers have filed an immediate appeal for release, and the court has two months to review it.
Sarkozy has expressed his innocence, stating, 'It is not a former president of the republic being jailed this morning, but an innocent man,' and believes truth will prevail.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Nicolas Sarkozy, former President of France, has begun a five-year jail term after being found guilty of criminal conspiracy involving illegal campaign funding from Muammar Gaddafi during his 2007 election campaign. He is the first former head of a European Union state to be imprisoned, and the first French leader since Nazi collaborator Philippe Petain to be jailed. Sarkozy has denied the charges and stated he is an innocent man, with his lawyers filing an appeal for release that the court will review in two months. He will be held in solitary confinement at La Sante prison, with limited interaction and scheduled visits, and has expressed hope that truth will prevail, even as the event marks a significant moment in French and European political history.
title: Former French president Nicolas Sarkozy starts five-year jail term
